MKlaene wrote:

> I'm having some concerns as I write some tests for my DAOs.  My
> concern is that I can't figure out a good way to write these tests
> without relying on other DAO methods.

Don't worry about this. As long as you test some methods on their own, 
feel free to use those (tested) methods to test others, especially if 
it's costly to avoid doing it.

Think of testing List.add() and List.contains(). You can't invoke 
contains() without having invoked add(), but that doesn't make it "bad 
form" to use add() to test contains(); or even to use contains() to test 
add()!

> I've looked at DBUnit.  The problem here is that I still have to
> populate my bean from the database - then I'm back to calling a DAO
> method like getEmployeeById in every method - an undesirable
> dependency.  Another option I guess would be to have some DAO
> methods used only for testing but this seems overkill.  I'd rather
> use the database during testing too, not mock objects.

Another option is to test using the back door: to test createEmployee(), 
use raw JDBC and a SELECT statement to ensure that the record is 
actually there.

That said, why would you rather use the database? Are you concerned that 
your JDBC driver doesn't work?

> So, I guess my questions are:
> 
> 1.)Is there a good way to test DAOs in isolation, without relying on
> other DAO methods?

Yes: use the back door (raw JDBC) to make assertions about database 
state at the end of the test.

> 2.)Does it really matter that much anyway if I use other DAO
> methods?  I mean, the goal is for ALL tests to pass anyway.  It can
> be confusing if your testDeleteEmployee method fails due to a
> failure in createEmployee which you have to call first, but I guess
> it wouldn't take long to figure out what really happened.

You could try this and observe the problems. I don't think there are 
many when the problem is small, but over time, testing your DAO against 
a real database becomes increasingly risky. Chapter 10 of _JUnit 
Recipes_ describes this in detail.

Take care.
